As part of our research program aimed to develope novel hybride molecules,”") considering above difficulties like the geometry, preparation of catalyst and multiple steps, we have developed new conventional synthetic protocol for the prepa- ration of natural products (Lansiumamide A & Alatamide (cis- isomer)) in the laboratory. Further, these two natural products are linked with phenylalanine through C—C bond to provide the new hybrid molecule and here in we wish to report our initial result. Subsequently, compound 1a was treated with oxalyl chloride in DCM solvent at ambient temperature to obtained acid chloride (2a). The compound 2a was combined with the blend of N-vinyl formamide (3a), Etz;N as well as a catalytic amount of DMAP in DCM at 0 °C and further stirring at RT for 2 h to provide compound 4a and it was forwarded to next step as such. Afterwards, the deprotection of formyl group of compound 4a was acquired by employing n-propylamine in DCM at room temperature. The compound 5a (Scheme 3) was purified by silica gel column chromatography and well characterized by 1HNMR & LC-MS. The characteristic terminal alkene protons of compound 5a were observed at 5 4.73 & 4.39 as doublet in 1HNMR. Further, compound 5a was subjected to bromination reaction by employing N-bromosuccinimide in DCM solvent at room temperature, however an expected yield was not obtained and many side products were obseved. Therefore we modified the reaction condition by taking 1 equ. of N- bromosuccinimide as well as 1.1 equ. of Et;N at 0 °C which lead to a higher yield of compound 6a. Thus, following these reactions, it is significant to mention that the formation of any di-brominated compound was not observed. The 1HNMR spectrum of the product of the bromination of compound 5a showed a doublet at 6 7.79 (J=15.20 Hz), which is character- istic of an alkene proton adjacent to a nitrogen atom.)

Further, several conditions of Suzuki coupling reactions with compound 6a and phenylboronic acid (7a) to obtained the Lansiumamide A (8a) which did not provide much success. We used _ Pd(dppf)Cl,/K;PO,/Dioxane:H,0/70°C, Pd(PPh;)CI,/ Cs,CO;/Toluene:H,0/70°C conditions however we did not observed any product formation. When the reaction was

The purification of 8a was carried out by using combi-flash column chromatography, and its identity was confirmed by 1HNMR and MS, as well as comparisons with literature data.??) Furthermore, the com- pound 8a was subjected to second bromination reaction by employing the similar reaction conditions of N-bromosuccini- mide and Et;N (Scheme 3). In the case of the synthesis of compound 13, the reaction was initiated by using commercially available D/L-phenylalanine.HCl (10). Compound 12 was pre- pared by carrying out a literature procedure”! (Scheme 3). The preparation of key boronate ester (compound 13) for both syntheses (Lansiumamide & Alatamide (cis-isomer)) was acheived by reacting compound 12 with _bis(pinacolato) diboron and KOAC in the presence of PdCl,dppf catalyst in 1,4- dioxane and cat. DMSO at 95 °C. The confirmation of compound 13 was performed by LC-MS analysis and used crude compound 13 without purification to next step Suzuki coupling reaction. Further, to obtain the Lansiumamide A- phenylalanine amino acid hybrid (14), we have tried several conditions of Suzuki coupling reactions were tried by changing Pd catalysts, bases, solvents and temperature. The subsequent efforts in conducting different conditions turned out to be ineffective. Finally, the compound 14 was obtained in a significant yield by using the compounds 9a as well as compound 13 in the presence of PdCl,dppf, K;PO, in 1,4- dioxane:H,O at room temperature. Compound 14 was charac- terized by 1H and 13 C NMR spectroscopy, FTIR and HRMS.”2 Having completed the synthesis of the Lansiumamide- amino acid hybrid, we decided to turn our attention to the synthesize Alatamide-phenylalanine amino acid hybrid (15). For the preparation of compound 15, similar synthetic protocol was utilized (Scheme 4). In a similar manner, to get the desired compound 4b, the iodination reaction was performed under N- iodosuccinimide and Et,;N at 0°C condition. The compound 4b alkene protons coupling constant value indicates that, com- pound 4b was in cis-isomeric form and it was charactarized by 1HNMR & LC-MS. Also, this same iodination reaction condition was used for the preparation of compound 8b. Further, to produce compound 5b and the final Alatamide (cis-isomer)- phenylalanine amino acid hybrid (15), the Suzuki coupling reaction consisting of two steps (Scheme 4; steps 4 and 6) was achieved by using the compound 7b, compound 13 under PdCl,dppf, K3;PO, in 1,4-dioxane:H,0 condition at RT. The compound 5b was established by 1HNMR and LC-MS. The results found that spectral values of compound 5b were compared with previous report’? and showed the stereo- chemistry of compound 5b was different than the previous report. In contrast with the previous result and the coupling constant value (J=9.2Hz at 5 5.86 doublet proton) of compound 5b showed the synthesized compound 5b was cis- isomer. Thus, the compound 15 was well characterized by 1HNMR, 13 C-NMR, FTIR and HRMS spectral data. From the successful results, it can be indicated that previously unattain- able Lansiumamide A-phenylalanine amino acid hybrid and Alatamide (cis isomer)-phenylalanine amino acid hybrids were prepared by Suzuki coupling of N-((E)-2-bromo-2-phenylvinyl) cinnamamide/(E)-N-(2-lodo-2-(4-methoxyphenyl)vinyl) benzamide with n-Boc phenylalanine methyl ester. Conclusion In summary, a novel and efficient route for the preparation of Lansiumamide A-amino acid as well as Alatamide (cis isomer)- amino acid hybrids was developed. The research revealed the first synthesis of C-linked Lansiumamide A/Alatamide (cis- isomer)-Phenylalanine amino acid conjugates where both the natural products were linked to amino acid through C—C bond.
